name: Qingqing L.
title: Anaplan to deliver multiple projects

1. Since business environment changes everyday, EPM solution with implementation flexiblility is more preferred, and Anaplan is such kind of platform which is easy for COE team to make changes in system according to new requirements.
2. Anaplan NUX pages include helpful native functions like filter, pivot, search etc., so end users can also custermize their analysis in certain level.
3. Anaplan can be used in multiple areas incl supply chain, FP&A, Tax etc.. The functions in Anaplan can support most of the operation/reporting needs from end users, so we help clients to realize their business process using single tool.

From development perspective, if Anaplan backend can provide a summary view for following information, it will be very helpful for teachnical lead to review and refine the model.
- Module/Saved View is used in which NUX page
- Saved View is used in which action
- Filter is used in which view or NUX page
- DCA is applied in which line item

Data :
Simplify the data integration and update flow. Anaplan can consolidate data from multiple external systems in to data hub, and all the business users will perform operations using same data and all the adjustment or changes will be reflected in solution in real time (Single source of truth)

Auditability :
Anaplan can track all the edit history from both front end and back end, and this auditability is usually requested by all the clients

Business : 
We use Anaplan to support multiple areas : 1. Supply Chain forcast and simulation 2. Tax provision 3. Human resource management 4. FP&A (Forecast Revenue and Expense) As a technology consultant, using

name: Kirill B.
title: Organization Planning
answers:
-Rest API easily integrates data to multiple downstream/upstream systems
-Can handle Complex Real Time Calculations on large data sets including Optimization and Machine Learning Algorithms
-Multi Level Security Options to define the right access level needed
-Fully Customizable easy to understand End User interface
-Cloud Based 
-Logic is Fully Customizable to handle any business use case (these can range from FP&A, Supply Chain, Manufacturing, Personnel Planning, Sales Territory, etc.) 
-Built in scheduling and automation features
-Allows to complex workflow process management
-Can handle 1000s of users inputs simultaneously 
-Frequency of Use:  monthly / daily / quarterly forecasting based on business requirements
-Excellent customer support
-Allows to follows true AGILE implementation methodology based on continuous user feedback during implementation

-Cost of data volume can be expensive; using the POLARIS feature should considered when if dealing with large multi-dimensional (>10 dimensions with over 1000 members in each dimension) sparce data sets
-Due to the customization of the platform to your specific business use case and requirements, the initial implementation will require the definition and testing of those requirements by the business
-Reporting capability is good, but due to cost of data storage, has to be limited in some cases to only the timescale necessary for planning purposes

Anaplan is allowing our company to plan for multiple business use cases within the same platform and integrate the planning data between use cases.  This means that business users interface with one planning tool regardless of if they are planning for supply chain, workforce, SG&A, CAPEX, Sales Volumes, Sales Territories, etc.  The flexibility of Anaplan and the ability to maintain Master Data within the tool has also allowed us to create planning and reporting structures that tie in mulitple source ERP systems. Anaplan - Connected Global

name: Andris I.
title: A great value add tool to any business process where decisions rely on solid and accurate data
answers:
It's flexibility as a tool and it's potential in many different areas of the business. It combines good data analytics with great user interface for planning. If built correctly it's fast, easy to use and reliable. 
The flexibility also extends to implementation scope and speed. If the criteria of implementation changes mid way through the project Anaplan has the features and flexibility to deal with almost every change thrown at it. 
They have a great learning platform that help speed up the understanding of Anaplan for both business users and future model builders, which greatly empowers the business users to keep the tool up to date.
Anaplan is a type of system which, if implemented successfully, sells itself inside the company, the more functions you get on the platform the larger the benefit of having such a platform can be achieved. It is very simple to integrate and synchronize different areas of Anaplan models between each other, like make your supply chain application deliver data automatically to jour finance application, doing away with long e-mail chains of finding the correct version of the plan to use. It also extends to 3rd party sources, Anaplan supports easy integration possibility with dedicated analytics tools or allows for a simple integration with source systems. It's fast and reliable and does not ask a lot of IT resources to set up. 
Once implemented Anaplan becomes a daily source of truth for the functions using it.

Their user management, specifically when it comes to licensing, can sometimes be a bit difficult to follow and properly track in the system. Although there have been good improvements lately with enhancements to global User Management views it still lacks an easy overview of contracted licenses vs used.

Anaplan standartizes the planning process, it makes data (especially results) transparent for the management team. Due to primarily replacing Excel-based planning processes it unlocks the possibility to work with more data and larger granularity of data faster. And not only that it allows that within a cross functional model where you might have multiple departments and business functions working in a seamless live model. 
With it's ML Timeseries forecasting capabilities and Linear Optimizer Anaplan can solve very complex business problems quickly across multiple functions although these two primarily have a direct impact on Demand Planning and Supply Chain, that then is passed down to finance or other parts of the business using the system.
You can also see buggs and user errors in the planning cycle dramatically decrease after implementing Anaplan. It's flexible enough so that the platform can be built around your business process, but the user interface can be made strict enough to ensure correct entries and reduction of user errors.

name: Sunil M.
title: Platforms in the Market
answers: Anaplan is a cloud-based planning and performance management platform that enables businesses to plan, budget, forecast, and analyze data in a collaborative and connected environment. Anaplan is a very Flexibile and Scalable platform due to hyperblocks/hyper models, very strong in Collaboration and Ease to Use which includes Ease of Implementation becasue of we can build models using Agile methodology. As Anaplan supports various planning areas in an organization we can build an enatire build Connected Planning environment  and can easily build Scenario Planning capabilities because of its multi dimensionality capabilities. Supports various types of Data Integrations and last but not least the product is continuously being innovated. Anaplan has great customer support
Inspite of a lot of advatanges, managing new development and production bug fixes is still a painful proicess. Need more innovation in UX pages versioning as the cganes in NewUX are mostly manual.

At Qualys, becasue of Anaplan the time for forecasting and Budgeting has been reduced drastically and the platform provides an amazing collabrative experience unlike excel. Pur CFO now can look at the budget and Forecast vs Budget vs actuals variance all in single place and is all live data unlike with excel where there were teams pulling multiple files and trying to aggregrate every week/month. Best Connected Planning

name: Charles P.
title: Kickstart your planning transformation with Anaplan
answers:
The ability to handle disconnected datasets and source information from systems that speak different "languages".  And to use this functionality to improve the data quality of forward-looking views and the decision quality of leaders using that information.  

Flexibility to tailor dashboards and data views based on user personas and roles.  The security model is infinitly flexible here and yet not difficult to configure.  

Scalability.  You can (and should) use Anaplan to improve a small, less risky business process but then branch out and broaden the scope to other areas that are not feasible with existing systems.  This really allows you to practice an agile approach to the improvement journey.

Some of the front-end dashboard functionalities could be improved.  Specfically, the lack of a multi-tab view of dashboards that you've viewed (or list of recently viewed) means you bounce around a bit.  The original (aka "classic") dashboard in Anaplan allowed this tabular view and users really liked that.  It would also help if you could do a "wrap text" like Excel and have the grid views auto-size the row heights.

We've used the product across about 20 use cases spanning each of our major businesses globally.  So, while each use case has its own business case and story, some general themes apply to all:

How it benefits...
- Anaplan has helped us integrate and streamline planning processes...particularly processes that span departments and teams spread globally but rely heavily on disconnected data sources like excel files and manual reconciliations of these sources with enterprise systems.  
- Anaplan has enabled a true "single source of truth" in a real-time environment catering to various user personas.  So, now we avoid the confusion over what "the number" is during peak planning periods with many iterations.
- Anaplan has helped us to overcome poor data quality from source systems by leveraging the flexible (and auditable) functionalities to normalize data and make the best use of it with stakeholders....vs. waiting until we "clean up" all of our source data challenges.

name: Michelle S.
title: Investment Industry
answers: Anaplan as a solution provides flexibility whilst creating a robust and secure environment to connect people, data and plans. It is the best placed tool I have come accross to replace the 'messy middle' and heavy dependence on modelling in excel. The platform allows you to build your processes, formulas and plans in line with the structure of your business and the ability to drill down provides transparency.  It allows for end to end planning accross your business.  In the Alternative Investment industry we have seen this clearly.  In additon to standard FP&A and Workforce Planning use cases Anaplan can truly offer a breadth of capabilities.  Real Estate firms use it plan the entire lifecycle of their assets from Acquistion Underwriting Models, through Developments, Asset Level Planning, Disposals and Fund Modelling.  Private Equity firms have seen value in building out Fund Outcomes models, Valuations, Carry Waterfalls and more.

Management Reporting has been a great new feature but it would be great to see this develop even further. Adding the TODAY function would also be useful and the ability to sub-total via a selection in reports

Time to value, with short implementation time-frames, Anaplans benefits rapidly realized.  The platform enables collaboration, provides one source of truth, enables security, version control and transparency. A Platform of Capabilities - Planning for the Alternative

name: Евгений .
title: Anaplan practice evolving all over the years
answers: Anaplan is a easy-to-use service, but still very powerful and robust at the same time. There is a quite low level of entrance to the platform in order to be able to create complex models. If you are good in excel and VBA, you will be definitely good in model building. You can cover any business case by Anaplan, it's proved by my 7-years platform's experience. An UX is great, you don't have to get used to that. It is very native and user friendly. Anaplan doesn't stay in an one place. It releases new features very often.

Unfortunately, Anaplan doesn't support any scripts modelling. Therefore, sometimes you have to pass a very long building way in order to reach your goal. The greatest disadvantage of the platform is a price. It is quite high, your company need to have a really good profit to afford it. On the other hand, Anaplan brings a real value. That amount can be calculated. In many cases the savings cover an Anaplan's TCO.

As a consultancy company, we've managed a lot of Anaplan implementations in different domains and business cases. It's been FMCG, Pharma, Banking, Mining, and Tech industries. All of them found their benefits in the Anaplan's implementation. Some clients cut twice their time for budget campaign, others increased transparency and efficiency in C&B process for their Sales Reps. Many clients provide a great feedback about an ability to create and compare different scenarios in very rapid way. In my opinion, the greatest benefit in the Anaplan implementation is that clients, finally, get verified and enhanced buisness process, that have really clear definition. In addition to that, they can change the process, even by their internal champion. Nowadays, when the things are changed unpredictably fast, this is extremely important. The

name: Douglas E.
title: Highly collaborative and customizable modelling software
answers:
How customizable it is. Companies can replicate their business processes with minimum to no compromise. It is one of the few tools on the market (with Excel) with this level of customization.
Anaplan is probably second only to Excel in project development time, it is incredibly fast.
Finally, given that it is a formula-based tool, there is no scripting needed so anyone can pick it up.

The user interface. Even though Anaplan has invested a lot of time and effort over the last couple of year to improve it (new user experience, management reporting,...) I don't believe it's quite there yet.
Simple things are still missing.
Additionally, proper workflow capabilities need to be re-introduced (Anaplan did release a v.1 in 2020).

Problems: siloed business processes, difficulties to consolidate the figures, multiple data sources, manual calculation/template errors, no audit trail, no data security
Benefits: time savings, live consolidated figures, single source of truth, accurate and correct calculations, advanced audit and security capabilities

name: Ivan L.
title: Anaplan replaced shared spreadsheets
answers:
Anaplan's security feature enable input data accountability. Its dashboards or reports update on the fly when data change. 
Its flexible modelling features allow seamlessly model update.  For example, when adding a new entity to entity list in a model, the same set of calculations will applied to the new entity straight away. No need to duplicate calculations for the new entity.

Dashboard functionality is not as flexible as excel. For example, font size in dashboard is not adjustable. Cell highlighting by user is not possible. Line item alias is not there, we need to create a separate line item to accommodate the reporting requirement.

Before Anaplan, we used spreadsheet for monthly workforce planning process which involves 20 cost centers and around 400 workforce resources. Some resources will be shared by multiple cost center, and it caused double counting in planning. To maintain the accuracy and integrity of data, a delegated staff responsible to meet with individual head of business functions and to input the workforce planning data for them. Also, it took the staff around 3-4 stressful days to produce a consolidation report. During these 3-4 days, any new-comer or resignation still need to be handled and updated to get an accurate report.
With Anaplan, individual head of business functions are able to input the workforce planning data themselves via the self-serve dashboard. With the control of cost center resources hierarchy, planning for shared workforce resources without double count become possible. Also, a cost center dashboard, which is impossible in spreadsheet model, allows the head of business functions to review their own workforce planning. Once the workforce planning data is completed by the head of business functions, the consolidation report is produced automatically. For any changes in resource, it reflects in the report immediately.

name: Alexander D.
title: The best solution for your planning and process needs
answers: I like that the user experience is really flexible and meets the main needs of most enterprises. The Connected Planning experience a good implementation can give to its customers is a high-end solution that works really well. The platform constantly expands and is market competitive, the multiple integration options allow the system to communicate and seamlessly fit in any existing environment.

Having been exposed to the gritty back-end work and not only the shiny front-end, there are things that can be enhanced in the way the dimensions work and the way the engine performs - being a live system means any blocking action cripples user experience for everyone involved.

Enterprises shifting their planning processes to a tool that can meet all their needs - processes can be clear and concise, and seamlessly interact with the overall business cases. Complex processes that span over multiple regions and business units are usually difficult to optimize or consolidate; however using Anaplan makes this step far easier to accomplish and maintain.

name: Dhruv S.
title: Anaplan for advanced modeling and connected planning
answers: Anaplan is an advanced modeling platform which connects people, data, and plans across the enterprise to a single source of truth. It allows for collaboration across various divisions and enables businesses to plan top to bottom and bottoms up across Finance, Sales , Supply chain, HR and other divisions. It has an intiutive User Interface which provides capabilities of latest Management Reporting functionalities as well. It is truly a revolutionary platform which definitely provides an edge to businesses using it. The plaform also has the ability to pull data from various sources through easily configurable in ETL's / File loads etc

Although anaplan is a highly scaleable and flexible platform, it is important to ensure that the foundations of the model are built correctly during any implementation to allow for long term sustainability and scaleability of the model. Anaplan is easy to learn and implement but in order to achieve scaleable models, in depth solution architecture experience is required

Anaplan allows to solve various business problems and supports unlimited use cases. Anaplan has enabled us to model FP&A budgets, Real Estate Valuations and Forecasting, Incentive Compensation Management , workforce planning and various other use cases. Across all use cases it has enabled users to easily model various scenarios and in real time view results of what if analysis on their plans.

name: Vinayak M.
title: Model builder Lense
answers:
Being worked on legacy products in the past, writing logics or formulas in Anaplan is much simpler & fast. Anyone with excel knowldege can easily build or atleast read calculations. 

The drill down functionality allows to easily trace back the calculations on the spot, no need to open backend tables or doing dummy calculations in excel to verify results.

The flexibility it provides to build only what's needed & structure the model as you want. This allows business to customize their models/processes the way they want rather than fitting your process into pre-configured planning softwares.
Though the model latency is outcome of how the model is built, bigger models usually face data latency or "model busy" or concurrency issues, not good with huge chunck of data.

In current project, we are streamilining the production & material planning for our client. Earlier each business unit had their own excel spreadsheets and used to work in silos, any business dicision/change used to happen over formal cimmunication channels and to reflect that decision took time. Now all these planning is being streamlined into Anaplan, stakeholders can have access to relevant data in real-time at one place & will speed up the decison making & planning. All the manual calculations, reporting will be automated & planners can focus more on planning rather than consolidating and prepariong reports for planning. Anaplan through

name: Chase G.
title: Excel replacement with endless possible uses
answers: I love the ease of building in Anaplan compared to the Excel documents I used to work with. The syntax is straightforward, and the drill-down feature makes it very easy to troubleshoot any issues while building out a User Story. Anaplan takes out all the validation issues that come along with end-users "fat fingering" a key and erasing data. Also, the history feature where you can view any change to a specific cell has been incredibly useful. When troubleshooting issues with end-users since I can see the exact action they ran and what order they performed the steps.

My major issue with Anaplan is the concurrency issues when running processes or editing cells. The first complaint I hear from any client is that there is a blue box on their screen preventing them from entering data.  I have minimized the time the actions run by following the best practices, but when there are multiple users in the system, it will inevitably happen. I know that I could remove actions from the end-users, but the clients ask for a way to input then submit. So therefore, I have to have a submission action.

The main problem I run across with all clients is the need to move from Excel because the file is too large and will not load/perform properly. Anaplan is the perfect tool for these cases because it can replicate excel almost precisely, giving the clients comfort, while also being a much more powerful tool that can handle large amounts of data without performance issues. Anaplan is a powerful
Anaplan is a sleek and powerful tool that can help you escape the large, slow, clunky Excel files you're dealing with today.

name: Douglas E.
title: Anaplan, best modelling tool for collaboration and flexibility
answers: Anaplan is almost as flexible as Excel. You can pretty much model anything you want and without the need to write scripts. Anaplan is probably the most flexible modelling tool on the market. This means people can stick to their models and don't have to conform to any other standard.

Just like Excel it is affected by the numbers of cells used in the model. Fortunately, we are talking here of billions of cells before running into any sort of issues but still. It would be great not having to worry about it.

Collaboration is drastically improved. People don't need to send each other spreadsheets or worry about formula errors. Multiple stakeholders can access the platform simultaneously but can only see the data they have access to. The calculations happen live without the need to refresh nor save anything.

name: Rachit S.
title: Versatile and powerful planning platform with focus on innovation, connected planning and community
answers: I like Anaplan's planning and modeling features, intelligent engine, user experience, extensibility and scalability. Anaplan connects people, data and plans like no other with their unified cloud platform. New features and functionalities are incorporated into the platform on a monthly basis which enhance the product's value proposition and usability significantly.

Auditability of line items can be improved by adding extra features like saved views references, filter references, UX page references etc. Native support for allowing input/breakback and calculation logic in the same line item can be added to further boost platform adoption in Retail Planning use cases.

Anaplan's versatility is one of its key differentiators. Using Anaplan, comprehensive planning solutions that facilitate quick decision-making can be built for all critical functions - Finance, Sales, Supply Chain, HR and Workforce, Marketing etc. As a partner, this enables me to implement best-in-class solutions for our customers and their planning needs.

name: Michael V.
title: How to increase data security by eliminating spreadsheets while breaking down silos
answers: Anaplan's security via self services, single sign on and central identify management allows planning teams to stop sending risky emails with attachments and to plan and review via dashboards.  By leveraging Anaplan, a centralized planning tool, the forecasting teams standardize processes, democratizes data via transparent data values and as a result breaks down silos.

Anaplan is currently not an out of the box solution, so implenting it requires dedication from the business. The Anaplan way, and working with partners helps organizations positvely transform their planning process, but in the end the buisness has to commit and invest in change.

Anaplan is providing transparency from start to finish in the planning process.  During C-Suite reviews, if anyone asks: "where does that value come from" the presentor can drill down into the value.  When previously preparing for C-Suite reviews, different parts of the organization may have calculated the same metrics with different logic or inputs, Anaplan forces the organization to provide transparency, alignment, and standardization where applicable to that planning process.

name: Vignesh M.
title: One Platform
answers:
Using Anaplan since 2016, seen how anaplan changed over period of time in every possible way from coding to UI....,
1. Anaplan continous focus on improvement of the platform,
2. Time to deploy the solution and scalability
3. Ease of coding

I like Anaplan a lot overall, however I believe there is space for improvement in UX to imporve usability, also some functionalities which exist in excel are not available and had to find a workaround which is not super complex.

Before Anaplan, we had to consolidate 100+ spreadsheet from asset managers from various location to be collected/combined to produce one top level report by Fund and Group, more time was spent on data collection, error checking, and reporting. 
After Anaplan, zero time spent for reporting as anaplan is powerful enough to produce real time consolidated reports, one platform to manage 100+ properties. Anaplan -  Planning in
Refer to the Apps in Anaplan App hub and check best practises articles like Planual and other Posts in community.

name: Jordan E.
title: Platform Review
answers: Anaplan is a great tool for taking companies to the next level of planning capabilities. The ability to connect an enterprise in real time drives down the time and cost of running a planning cycle and pivoting based on new challenges and changing variables.

It can take a while to get used to the model building approach and reshaping your brain to think in multidimensional terms, especially if coming from a traditional planners toolkit (Excel). I will say the training does a good job of being thorough and on demand.

Anaplan is solving a vast array of my customers' problems, across industries and use cases. I have implemented Anaplan for fast food chain restaurants, oil & gas, healthcare, SaaS companies. Anaplan's flexibility can tackle any industry and any challenge presented. Anaplan

name: Nikhil L.
title: Planning and Beyond
answers:
I like the most about Anaplan is the customization capability and ease of development and usage. You can build anything and everything using your imagination and modeling skill sets. Anaplan has transformed the way connected planning solutions are thought through and developed.

Anaplan always keeps up with new features and requirements needed to keep the tool most up to date... new functionalities like Polaris engine, Workflow, DMS are a testimony to that fact.

Sometimes it feels an overkill that certain functionalities are unavailable in Anaplan, and everything has to be developed through a custom code. Things like Delta functionality, more robust auditing capabilities, drill-through capabilities, and model locking are some of the things which come to mind.

From a developer perspective, Anaplan provides endless possibilities to offer solutions to the client per outlined requirements. It's the next-gen EPM solution to cater to all the different use cases and Business areas in the organization. Anaplan - Connecting

name: Brian S.
title: Chain Planning
answers: Anaplan is a very powerful modeling engine. It can handle large loads of data crossing multiple dimensions and calculate them in real time. It's highly scalable and very robust

The biggest struggle with Anaplan has been their slow implementation of a fully functional new UX. I agree with their decision to replace the old interface, but it took several years for the new UX to get to a point where it seemed acceptable for an enterprise tool. There are still a few quirks here and there, but it is by and large a great UX.

The ability to connect data across the organization allows for very powerful planning capabilities. What Anaplan calls "Connected Planning", allows for a holistic solution to all aspects of planning. This means you're not using disparate systems, spreadsheets, emails across departments. You have instant access to a 'source of truth' that everyone is sharing and working off of together. Highly Recommend for Finance, HR and Supply

name: SJ E.
title: Anaplan is a flexible tool that is great for complex organisations!
answers: Anaplan is a strong tool for finance as it can be built for a variety of business processes. Its flexibility allows us to customise the tool for each unique aspect of the business. While it is extremely flexible, it is important to have the right people in place to help manage the tool long term. Implementations for Anaplan are quick and you can easily deliver an MVP and then continue to add on additional features throughout the year in releases. Users enjoy working with the tool because of the UX - if dashboards are built with a strong user journey in mind.

The auditing feature is not very user friendly. The export of history must be exported. parsed and displayed on a separately built dashboard to be useful. 
Security is too broad and not centrally managed (but this is being worked on!)
More work needs to be done to make integration and data management easier (again being worked on!)

Anaplan is centralising the planning processes and helping with version control and collaboration. There is more visibility into the numbers behind calculations and stronger processes are being formed internally to help systemitise budgeting and forecasting processes.

name: Verified User in Venture Capital & Private Equity
title: Calculation Engine
answers: Anaplan standardizes and promotes healthy processes and workflows within a business. It centralizes key hierarchies which are used across multiple calculations and business units, ensuring everyone is on the same page and eliminating duplication of work effort.

The new UX has a grid system that does not lend itself to holding a lot of data on one dashboard. However, the improved user interface is more attractive than the previous iteration referred to as "classic dashboard"

Anaplan is a robust calculation engine that regularly uncovers longstanding errors within excel processes. In all of my clients, once processes are moved or rebuilt in Anaplan, we have found long standing formula errors and irrelevant hardcoded values when reconciling to Anaplan. Anaplan is incredible flexible and I have personally used it across multiple use cases (monthly FP&A reporting, revue forecasting, HR management, recruitment, WFP, data hub, budget consolidation, comp planning, waterfalls) Versatile

I would highly recommend Anaplan as a calculation engine. It is an incredibly flexible tool that allows users to pick up the syntax and self govern easily compared to other systems. However, I would fully understand the reporting capabilities and limitations prior to signing on. With that in mind, I believe Anaplan is most powerful when coupled with a reporting tool such as Tableau

name: Michael A.
title: A great "connected" planning tool that can scale with your business
answers:
* Encourages collaboration across business units to break down silos
* Can easily add more granularity to existing planning models
* Relatively fast implementation timeframe
* Numerous integration options including Anaplan APIs, Anaplan Connect, HyperConnect and iPaas connectors
* Drilldown feature which enables a user to trace calculations back to source inputs/data
* Dynamic reporting through the use of dynamic text where values (e.g. Sales or Net Profit) dynamically change as the user selects different reporting periods
* Workflow feature although this currently costs a small license fee 
* Customer focussed support

* Certain aspects of model building are more complicated that it needs to be... although has improved recently and continues to evolve
* Some new features (e.g. Workflow) require additional licence fees to be paid
* Uses a different platform to handle very large models

Our clients who have implemented Anaplan were primarily wanting to:
- remove/limit the use of MS Excel in managing and driving the performance of their business to eliminate inherent spreadsheet mistakes and provide transparency in assumptions/drivers used in planning models
- encourage collaboration among their business units
- significantly reduce the time it took to report their results and prepare updated forecasts
- introduce a faster way of creating scenario analyses to enable them to react to fast changing market conditions and plan for unforeseen challenges

name: Verified User in Financial Services
title: Consistent in demonstrating tangible value & enhancing user experience
answers:
I like that Anaplan can always show exciting results to clients quickly.  Even if a model is only in its infancy, the client can still see the vast benefits offered & the real-time savings they get out of it.

I love the scalability and emphasis on embracing connected planning principles.  By doing this, organizations can realist sustained improvements that have the ability to expand beyond just the current use case.  These concepts seamlessly translate to an intuative user experience for all stakeholders.

Sometimes Anaplan can be so dynamic that seemingly effortless things are missing from the model builder or user perspective. An example can be publishing specific page selectors in different areas, ease of filtering, etc.  Another specific example would be native time filtering options when building in a module with 'Time' as a dimension.

However, Anaplan has made a lot of strides with these features both in the classic model building mode and the UX.

I have solved problems related to a lot of manual work in excel.  Many clients are hampered by vigorous offline processes that take forever to complete, which eats into time better spent elsewhere.  There have also been complex allocation pain points that Anaplan has alleviated.

Anaplan has also helped us achieve connectivity across organiztion.  It has improved accuracy and synergy across different processes that has enabled effective growth and expansion.   Once clients realize the how Anaplan can enhance connected planning, it leads to increased adoption & enthusiasm for the product.

I would recommend Anaplan as a solution for any business.  The benefits are limitless, and the interface is friendly and easy to use.  You will instantly see benefits if you have dedicated personnel helping implement and maintain.  Clean data and a clear roadmap & vision are essential to successfully using this tool.

name: Stuart M.
title: Anaplan a flexible planning tool with many use cases
answers: Anaplan is a multi-dimensional planning tool that allows you to bring together multiple sources of data to act as the one source of truth for planning.  With versions and flexible time scales, you can plan for any eventuality as far out as you need to.
The lack of workflow was an issue, butAnaplan has implemented this recently and looks to provide what we need. It good to know they listen to their customer base.

Anaplan acting as the one source of truth for your data allows greater faith in the numbers throughout the business. it also speeds up the whole reporting process allowing more agile planning throughout the business.

name: Anton S.

name: Verified User in Computer Software
title: Model Builder
answers: I like that Anaplan is a massive upgrade relative to other tools (like Microsoft Excel) in terms of empowering users to drive connected forecasting and planning.  There are so many features that make this empowerment possible, such as version control, real time calculation updates, and dynamic cell access.

When an Anaplan Model Builder attempts to implement a formula that is invalid, sometimes, this results in the Anaplan model locking up (or "toasting") for a period of time that ranges from seconds to minutes (depending on the size and complexity of the model) while the model processes and reverts the change.  During this "toaster" period, no one, including Model Builders and users, can navigate or make changes in the model - This is extremely disruptive.

Through Anaplan's Application Lifecycle Management functionality, I can Model Build in an existing Anaplan model without disrupting users' working in the Production model.  Thanks to Anaplan's Hyberblock technology, I can build models containing data and calculations that far exceed anything I can build in other tools in terms of size and calculation complexity.  Due to the ability to build and manage Anaplan models without help from a typical Information Technology (IT) team, I'm empowered to develop solutions for our users with minimal overhead or reliance from non-business teams. name: Brian S.
title: Anaplan is a strong multi-dimensional modeling platform for large and complex data sets
answers: Most of my engagements on Anaplan have been around financial planning with very large and complex data sets. Anaplan's ability to allow you to slice, dice and join data to calculate forecasts is something I haven't seen on any other platform.

The top issue I have with Anaplan is the 'clunkiness' of the UX. While a lot of progress has been made since it's inception in 2018-2019, it continues to be sluggish when it comes to loading pages. Users also complain about the "model is busy" message that doesn't tell them why it's busy. In the classic UX you could see the name of the person who is tying up the model -- aka the "toaster" -- but that doesn't appear in the UX.

In my current engagement, we are using Anaplan to create both Current Quarter and Long-Term Forecasts for Orders, Revenue and Margin for a large Telecom company. We have over 30 data sets that are used in order to do this, meaning that Anaplan is being used to slice, dice and join these data sets to allow us to forecast. This includes Salesforce data, Oracle data, contract data, transit time data and numerous others. I can't even count how many spreadsheets and manual processes we are replacing with this model.

name: David E.
title: Anaplan provides strong use cases across multiple industries
answers:
The live calculation engine allow users to see the effects of their updates in real time, which places Anaplan at the top tier of planning solutions. Centralizing information also allows users to view changes from other parts of our organization, which drives more efficient planning cycles and communication among departments.

The new user experience is also industry-best. Dashboarding translates cleanly to the mobile application, and on-screen views are professional and effective for communicating data to higher level users.

I have been involved with Hyperion and TM1 implementations in past roles, and Anaplan is by far the easiest and fastest to implement. Changes on-the-go are also very efficient to roll out, which is not the case with more complicated and less-sophisticated platforms. For organizations that experience dynamic lines of business, Anaplan is an ideal solution for quickly developing what-if scenario analysis to reduce uncertainty and promote smarter forecasting.

Managing large amounts of data presents a challenge at times. Due to Anaplan's configuration as a planning tool, there is a trade-off between calculation speed and data storage capabilities. Many times, our users would like to see highly specific, transaction level details within Anaplan, but due to the size of our organization, this is generally an impossible task to accomplish without exceeding the maximum allowed workspace size parameters.

Reporting is also not a strong suit for Anaplan. Most of our users are used to more flexible ad-hoc reporting similar to what is offered in Excel from Hyperion or TM1, so creating reports to match the capabilities of other tools often presents challenges. However, as with all things in Anaplan, the more time you spend in the system as a developer, the more you are able to find solutions for previously unsolvable problems.

In my work, my clients have solved issues around workforce planning, financial analysis, executive reporting, Capex and depreciation, cost allocations, real estate investment and property management, data integrations, and model security management. All of these areas have added significant efficiency around our planning cycles (reduced forecast/budget completion time, better communication across departments, greater visibility into cost savings drivers).

Your success with Anaplan is measured by the amount of knowledge and investment you make in learning the platform. Any company needs to invest in a full-time staff to support the system, which will increase user adoption as well as grow the use case potential within the organization. I have yet to run into a situation that cannot be solved with Anaplan, but it took time, creativity and an architectural focus to design solutions that had not yet been discovered by other developers.

name: Aaron O.
title: Robust modeling and insightful analytics with growing collaboration
answers: Anaplan does a phenomenal job of modeling data. If you can provide Anaplan the data relationships, it can show you deep insights and allow you to perform extensive scenario analysis. In short, it is the answer to making big data useful. No one sifts through thousands or millions of transactions to see patterns and trends. Anaplan gives you the tool set do it. Additionally, Anaplan is build-to-suit; the answer to 'Can Anaplan do it?' is almost always 'yes'; it can consume and enhance your current data structures as well as provide the foundation for bona fide process transformation.

While the nature of the tool promotes collaboration in the planning process through its role functionality, the day-to-day collaboration is not mature yet. There is room to grow in workflow and collaboration-specific functionality (e.g. comments in-platform).

As an implementation partner, I help companies solve a variety of problems with Anaplan. I primarily focus on sales performance management (SPM), so I will comment from that perspective. The most pervasive business problems that are solved by Anaplan are developing and managing territories and setting and adjusting quotas for the sales force. Most organizations lack any type of enterprise-level solution that does this, and the most frequent 'system' that is replaced is Excel. Anaplan provides a single source of truth for territories and targets; it allows for collaboration around that single data set and holistic data analytics that provide insights from an individual sales rep to mid-level managers to executives who oversee regions, business units, and entire organizations. The most potent advantage that is realized is the ability to view high-level KPIs, but to then drill into the details at a low level to understand what is driving them.
The platform's pricing is based on allocated space, which means that it can change over time and is subject to the data you load and the capabilities that you utilize in the platform.

name: Angela B.
title: Scalable, customizable, and intelligent platform for all your business planning needs
answers: Anaplan is not an out of the box solution that forces companies to fit their business process into a predefined mold, it allows businesses to build up models and planning processes that fit their needs and can continue to evolve as their business grows and changes. It is difficult to imagine a modeling scenario you can't build in Anaplan. The tool allows for a lot of flexibility in the type of planning a customer wants to do, and can truly be owned/managed by end users instead of by IT. This allows for much quicker turnaround on adjustments to a model.

Since Anaplan is not a pre-built solution, it does require more up-front investment in time and resources to get set up. It requires participation from multiple groups across the organization to put together a well-thought out model and more importantly to maintain and update the model on a regular cadence to keep up with a growing company. This can allow for things that shouldn't exist in Anaplan to be put into Anaplan (such as data storage).

I also think ANaplan's front end and reporting capabilities could vastly improve the appeal of the platform, this could help reduce a customer's need for separate reporting/dashboarding in another tool like Tableau and further streamline processes by having robust reporting directly in Anaplan.

Anaplan very quickly solves a lot of issues around internal communication and transfer of information because it is cloud based. Instead of having multiple versions of documents, a "living" version of business plans sits in Anaplan where anyone from the organization can access to review and make changes. This in itself reduces a lot of the time spent on planning. Through implementing Anaplan solutions at multiple clients, across several industries and use cases,  I have consistently found that having a dedicated model admin that knows how to build and adjust the model on the client side is most effective, it allows the client to view and approach using Anaplan as an App that requires regular updates and releases of updates to end users, rather than a one-time set up.

Have a clear plan for the future state process you would like to have in Anaplan before starting on building Anaplan; this will make the build easier, faster and ultimately result in a better model output. If you try to design a process during the build, it can quickly get messy as things are built/rebuilt or the direction is changed halfway through the build.

name: Iain B.
title: Powerful planning and modelling engine
answers_raw:
* Anaplan is reliable, fast and guarantees consistent calculations are applied across very large datasets. 
* A cloud base collaborative platform means there is no need to email files to colleagues and everyone is viewing real time data
* Easy to learn and intuitive platform with natural language syntax and a customisable user interface. With no particular IT background, I found it easy to learn as an experienced Excel user
* All the data in Anaplan's hyperblock is like a giant pivot table meaning reports and tables can be repivoted with different dimensions in a few seconds
* Anaplan has a limited (but fast improving)  range of formatting options
* Anaplan is a sophisticated platform and it can be tricky for end users to drill-down through some calculations
* Model building requires skilled and experienced resources which can be hard to find, although the Anaplan community is growing fast.
I work in finance and have implemented Anaplan for FP&A, overheads cost allocations, and long-term contract accounting. It is an extremely flexible tool with a large number of potential use cases beyond finance. The key benefits realized are shorter model turn-around times, primarily made possible through less manual intervention and less manual error. With much greater confidence in the results, this frees up time to interpret results and have better conversations with the business.

The best attribute that helps Anaplan's long term success with clients is how the models can be adapted to move with the business, so as the business and its environment changes, the model can adapt and stay relevent. Which stops users reverting back to Excel

Integrated P&L > Balance Sheet > Cashflow

IFRS Modelling Contract Revenue

Private Equity Fund modeling
Looking backward at investor level to calculate provisions, and looking forward for the rest of the fund's life at a deal level. To determine the expected returns on investment. The main benefit for the client is providing a solid platform to bring together their actuals plus the ability to overlay what-ifs for the outlook and compare multiple scenarios against each other. The inputs being at a level high enough for fund managers to relate to, but the underlying logic is very detailed to the extent of making decisions on when to call from or distribute to investors in a more life like way

Supply vs Demand modelling
In a range of industries, including energy, telecoms, and consumer goods. The principle is fairly similar for all of these industries, matching supply and demand, identifying variances. name: Verified User in Consumer Electronics
title: Simple, powerful, and easily leveraged
answers: The best part about using Anaplan is the ease of connecting models & various use cases into a consolidated format for the end users. For example, a P&L can be the backbone of a reporting model with smaller calculation models that feed the end result. This allows the models to be more granular in nature without affecting the main submission model and reduces performance impacts on the main model.

Some functions are limited (like subset of versions, subsets of users), but there are workarounds that the community has suggested. The roadmap is constantly developing and we are seeing some issues addressed with the releases. One major aspect that is recently being addressed is the key word highlighting when writing formulas. It is still in its infancy and has a bit of ways to go before it can be fully utilized.

Our use cases currently include aggregating a bottoms-up forecast for financial metrics, allocations of sales data for more granular visibility into performance, a bottoms-up calculation to determine COGM by product and region. It ultimately shortens time to understand where the numbers are coming from; perform allocations with minimal interaction; integrates with 3rd party platforms via APIs. We have seen a reduction in errors per forecast and time required in the model.

Spend the time upfront to flesh out your data structures & feeds - it can save you many headaches once you're knee-deep building a model. Keep a close relationship with the ones building integrations and tables in your warehouse if you don't have a resource dedicated to your team. Otherwise, it can be cumbersome to develop the proper connections for your data automation processes.

name: Paul O.
title: So, good luck
answers: <v ->Hello, my name is Paul O'Malley</v> and I am the GM of Commercial Accounting for Blue Cross. Blue Cross is a residential age care provider in Victoria, in Australia. We also have a number of home-care clients across a number of services, CHSP, VHC, DVA, private and home care packages. And I would rate Board eight out of 10. Board was initially brought into Blue Cross to solve a number of questions. One, about having one source of truth for our data. The other was around sharing financial data with our residents' managers more quickly and effectively. And also, having a further, deeper dive into our labor costs. Labor costs are about 65 to 75% of the revenue of the business. And so, Board was the tool that was going to unlock a deeper dive analysis into that cost every month. Good thing about Board is it links complex data sets from a number of systems. Once you have data and you have a mapping to overlay on top of the data, you can link it. We have multiple payroll systems for TNA, Rightech and Inova, and we pull all that data into our financial system, AIM, and we were able to link it to unlock a number of reporting that's very, very useful to us. Sick leave reporting, annual leave, long service leave, hours reporting to compare actual versus budget. The screens that you build in Board are also very, the length to allow dashboard creation, very easy and simple. They're simple to use. And it's also a very good tool to compare information effectively. I wouldn't say I'm overly negative about Board, but there are some things that we have found difficult, such as data that just disappears. Now, I need to probably quantify that in that we have had very, very successful dealings with Board and our partner Light Arch to fix all of our problems very quickly. So the data disappearing is probably the biggest one. There was also, historically, we had built a lot of old reports that our business wanted to just maintain that as we rolled forward, and so, rebuilding those old reports in Board was quite difficult, rather than, which I think the simple thing would be to just reboot everything and just build it as the system supports, which we didn't do. There's a couple of important things that you need to be very clear on. You will need someone in your team that knows your data very, very well. A data scientist or someone with very strong systems and data understanding. Once you have that person in place, you probably need to build out a data dictionary for every report or every piece of information that you need to bring from the systems into Board. That's the key, having that set up at the very start, knowing what your, if something does go wrong in the implementation phase, you always have that data dictionary to go back to, to compare, what did we start out this process to achieve, and have that set at the start. And I think patience. We've rolled Board out to over 70 members of our organization, and it takes time. You need to maintain the system well, maintain people's expectations of the system well. When, say for example, if Board doesn't update overnight, there needs to be a test at the start in the morning to make sure that you know that in advance so that the users don't get frustrated that our Board didn't update last night. So it's kind of having a good framework for how you're going to manage the rollout and implementation of the system and how you are going to administrate the system once it's out there and you've got a number of users on the platform. And then, have fun. It's a great system. It hasn't got many limitations. And really, it's a very fun process going from data to implementation and then to actually using the system.

name: Verified User in Packaging and Containers
title: Excellent professional services, solid system, average system support
answers: Board allows us to consolidate our financial data from multiple systems in a consistent manner at a reasonable price and output financial reports that are ready to be distributed to external users once validated.

System maintenance is not dynamic; we spend a lot of time managing specific setups in our ERP and have to replicate in Board manually. We wish this could be an interface, though perhaps that was a possibility, and our design didn't allow it. I wasn't with Altium when the system specs were designed and agreed upon. Also, although their professional services team was fantastic during and post-implementation, I haven't had as much luck with the traditional support path of creating a ticket with their support team. The few times I tried, the tickets took a long time to be addressed, and the answers weren't very helpful, which shows a knowledge transfer gap between the professional services team and the support team as to system specifics that are unique to a given customer's environment. Also, it is tough to make changes in the system without a Board consultant or having someone highly skilled in Board's complex design by cube. Although we implemented their Budgeting and Forecasting module, it quickly became useless as we made changes in our business that we couldn't easily adjust for within the system. Another comment is that there are too many manual steps in the Consolidation process from start-to-end.
The system allows us to gather data from multiple ERPs, in different currencies (currently only USD and CAD) and consolidate it into a finished set of financial reports.

name: Gregory D.
title: BI solution, easy to start with and advanced to cover all business needs
answers:
It takes a small amount of time from the first steps in Board to the creation of the first report.
When I train new members of my team I insist on understanding the basics of Board, similar to bricks, and then little by little build their solution, but even after a day of learning the solution they can start seeing their first report.
But for more advanced users you can use a collection of basics to build a more complex solution that will support your activity, from financial management to sales forecast and plenty more.

The usage of Data trhough dimensions can help you crafting the report you need rather than using the report you have.

Compared to other solutions, your consultants are the one doing all the construction, from Data model to capsule, everything can be handled by one person without prior knowledge in any development language.

One element to keep in mind for a good design of a Board solution : always have a clear picture of the final product before starting development.

The update process of Board is not aligned with other solutions. Rather than offering an updater, it requires a 2 steps action to uninstall and reinstall the solution.

Also, new functionalities are available in the Cloud version when the On-premise is not receiving them or at a later date.

Error messages in the application can be clarified to support a better understanding of the issues and maintenance of the solution.

name: Chris B.
title: Great for stalemate situations
answers:
We first started using Board during a period of time toward the end of our pipeline  where we were focusing on what had worked and didn't work during this particular project. After a session of team lead post mortem, we were able to dedicate resources to looking at new software, techniques and work flows going forward into the next project.

One of these was Board, and even in these stages of reflection, what surprised the team in general was how much Board was already helping in our search for research and development, even at this stage.

For situations where a logical and correct decision was to made, or even just planning a clear path toward a first goal or objective, the fluidity of Board and it's easy to understand nature, brought everyone together in solidarity of one clear aim.

the overall problem that we found was being able to roll this out from a small team scenario into wider parts of the company or other teams. I feel if everyone had been on board from the start (excuse the pun), we would have been able have a clear and correct way of working.

Rolling Board out in stages required continued explanation, and a much bigger effort of transition than would have been ideal. That said, this could have been short sightedness internally having come at this apporach from a brainstorm and research and development phase of the project.

Going forward I would recommend having Board integrated into your workflow from the start

Analysis is absolutely key, and the ease and intuitive nature of Board just made things so much clearer with regard to setting goals and the path to each one. we were able to easily discuss and implement solutions to each ares of our planning stage knowing that the process would become automated in it's own right as we continued through with out pipeline.

The interactive dashboard alone was a real eye opener in being able to share ideas and opinions. Everyone was up to date and on the same page with every piece of relevant information you could want, laid out in a clear and concise manner.

If you, or a team you are working with deals with any form of marketing, Sales or HR, then you will absolutely need a system like this in place, and you could do alot worse than Board. I feel as the company grows, and there are more and more users working centrally from one system of analytics, the presence of Board and of it's service will only get stronger and more refined.

Test it with key members of the team already dealing in the roles mentioned above, get everyone on board from the start, and they will all be able to be well informed, and make decisions with concise clarity.

We frequently use BOARD at our company, at a user level and also at an administrative level. It can be quite intimidating at first, but after a lot of patience and practice it can significantly improve the workflow in the workplace.

The relieve and luxury of building complex reports and dashboards automatically through the software is extremely beneficial. The speed of completing tasks increases to a considerable degree and leads to a more productive work environment.

BI allows us to effectively plan and control information technology investments across different locations, business units and subsidiaries – allowing them to used for our business’s needs. 

These features coupled together effectively reduce our required work, it’s very automated and reduces a lot of manual work we would have to otherwise do.

We haven’t identified many flaws with BI, although there are very insignificant issues such as importing large volumes of data can cause some problems with the dashboard and summary tables. 

Also, after updating to the latest version of the software, we have experienced some small bugs and glitches which can cause some difficulty when we’re testing. This can slow down the speed of work as we need to wait for the next patch version which would resolve these bugs.

Using BOARD effectively improves the workflow in our workplace significantly. Importing and working with massive amounts of data is quite straightforward to deal with on BI. It allows us to work with data really quickly to produce workable solutions.
Possessing a solid and persistent comprehension of your existing databases is highly recommended. It is crucial to understand what your data actually is before performing complex operations on them.

Software is easy to install and backup is simple.

There is permission control where data access can be set to different groups of users.
Accounting periods can be locked after each import which prevents accidental overwriting of past data.
Data import error messages can be improved to provide more information on why a record failed to get imported.

We lack a good presentation of consolidated data to customers and senior management and BOARD's slick graphics solved that. It allows various graphical presentation using the same set of data and the drill-down of details can be done from the reports directly. 
Tabulated data can be printed and exported to excel directly.
This is the tool for pretty presentation and is sufficient for non-technical users.

name: Rob B.
title: A very impressive product
answers:
Probably my favourite aspect of Board is the slickness of the presentation, with very little experience it's possible to create impressive and feature rich dashboards that go way beyond what I've seen from a lot of other products, and this is something which is only getting better and better in the new versions they're releasing.

The second thing I really like is the drill-down functionality - any table or chart can be drilled into by the end-user to explore the data which makes up the figures shown with just a couple of clicks, not only does this add hugely to the user experience, but it has also drastically reduced the number of queries we get regarding data provenance and completeness.

There are still some aspects of Board which need work, most are actually fairly small things such as GUI improvements which would simply give a better user experience (most noticeably at the back end for the developer). Many of the limitations such as chart customisation features have been addressed in the most recent releases.

As with most companies increasing data visibility and encouraging proper analysis are our primary goals, historically BI has often been treated as little more than an extension of source system reporting in our company, however using Board has enabled us to really hammer home to our users just how valuable proper analysis can be, and how much easier it can make their jobs at time. We've also finally managed to get a consolidated global picture of our client base without the need for a lot of manual number crunching and enormous Excel spreadsheets, something which is already paying huge dividends in terms of understanding how our client base varies by global region and the potential opportunities that offers for leveraging existing relationships.

If you have large datasets and you're looking for a tool which will allow you to surface that data in meaningful and easy to use ways, you could do a lot worse. I've found Board to be quicker than most other tools both for loading large datasets and for subsequently reporting on them.

name: Martin G.
title: Vena has transformed our forecasting and reporting process
answers: Vena is simple to use and gives us the flexibility to build our forecasting/reporting process to meet the demands and expectations of the business. The support team are friendly and are on hand to resolve any issues we have in an efficient manner, understanding our set-up and the problems we are trying to solve. All our business leaders and finance team use Vena to manage their numbers, using the workflows to review and sign-off on a monthly basis. It is used daily by all stakeholders and it has given time back to the leadership team to focus on more strategic activities as they now trust in the data that they receive.

I think understanding the full capabilities of Vena and getting the rest of the team trained up to get full use out of the tool takes time. There are also some templates that we have bespoked that can run a little slower due to the size of the files and number of formulas contained within them.

Vena has completely removed our offline process with manual email approvals. It has standardised the way we perform our forecasting and reporting cycle with workflows to ensure the data is reviewed and signed off in a timely manner. It has enabled us to speed up our month end forecasting by simplifying the way we input forecasting and balance sheet data. The senior management team now have access to data in a single place so we now have one source of the truth. The businesses now trust in the data that they receive as we have automated the workforce and financial data into Vena, along with them now owning their forecasting without having multiple versions of files with different data sets. We are constantly finding new ways to utilise Vena and provide the business leaders with better, faster data to manage their businesses more effectively.

name: Todd G.
title: VENA is the workhorse of our financial systems
answers:
1.  VENA is powerful  |  A a construction company, we started with job-level data in VENA but quickly moved to modeling whole divisions and the entire company in VENA.
2.  VENA is easy to use  |  Based on existing tools we use everyday (Excel) for I/O communication with VENA, it requires virtually no training for our teams to immediately begin using.
3.  VENA overdelivers value  |  Most software overpromises and underdelivers.  VENA makes promises carefully, then overdelivers.  We run our entire ERP using VENA, including quote management, job  management, and financial reporting.
4.  The VENA team is supportive  |  We have had nothing but success using the VENA team to train our small IS staff to substantially manage VENA on our own.
5.  VENA works seamlessly with our existing systems and processes.

1.  VENA can appear low tech becasue data is rendered in Excel.  The answer to this is to implement Power BI which we are doing now.
2.  VENA is super flexible and super powerful.  But it can be so flexible that little changes ripple through the data and challenge the resulting reports.  Careful management of all inputs and auditing existing data is mandatory.  But that is true of any system.

Essentially, VENA is our sole ERP system so it solves the sales process (pre-construction), job management (construction), and financial reporting (close and resultant reports).  All in, VENA performs as our CRM, our PM and our FPA.  We manage budget-to-actual at the job level, the divisional level and the entity level all in VENA.  We load new data as needed to augment our insights and bring data to the point of decision for our project teams.

Our source systems are API friendly so we just use flat files to integrate.  The ETL jobs run really fast and are easy to use.

name: Noris P.
title: One of the best decisions we've ever made
answers: There is a bunch to like with Vena, but I think the biggest selling point is that the end interface is something that everyone is familiar with: Microsoft Excel. Partnering with a tool that has been the industry standard for budgeting for years was an excellent move, and one we enjoy dearly. Besides that, it is very easy to ramp up your learning on the platform, implementation can be completed in under a week, and they have an excellent source of consultants and internal success managers that will make sure that you succeed in your journey. We started with a Financial data model but have also moved our revenue forecasting into its own cube that can easily communicate with the other to pull in Budget, Actual, and Reforecast data seamlessly. If anyone is on the fence about taking the leap, feel free to find me on LinkedIn and I will run you through my experience.

The few issues we've had over the years were resolved within a day or so, so there is not much to dislike. They listen to their customers and you can actually see your suggestions get baked into future releases, which is exactly what you want for in an ISV.

We have streamlined our budgeting process, and it comes preloaded with automated emails that go out along the process, smart dates for due dates, auditing, approvals/rejections. It should be the de facto solution for anyone that is currently struggling with their yearly budgeting and then periodic reforecasting cycles. We have also integrated our revenue forecast data into Vena, and we plan on actually exporting a portion out into R, run it through a model and then sync it back into Vena for our more variable usage components to get closer to a 99% CI. Within the next year we also plan to integrate our HRS into Vena so that we can establish a place for our HCM to be done in a more seamless fashion.

name: Doug V.
title: The perfect blend of power features and ease of use
answers: The well designed data cube allows administrators and power users great flexibility in data structure and template creation.  At the same time, casual users can easily enter data, run reports, create ad hoc queries, and drill to details.  Vena has replaced all of the high maintenance Excel workbooks used to create budgets and generate financial statements in the past.  It allows us to quickly consolidate a complex organization with more than 100 entities and easily report on any level, from a full division to a single location.
The user security features do their job but are probably the least intuitive part of the system.

Gathering input from dozens of contributors was a challenge with standard Excel workbooks.  Users might change formulas, move rows or columns, and generally wreak havoc, then expect Finance to put all the pieces back together.  Consolidating the budget or forecast was difficult with fertile ground for errors.  Because Vena stores everything to a central database with always connected and protected templates, a rolled up view is available on demand and without grief.  The cherry on top is an audit trail that can tell you exactly who changed what numbers and when.

Because Vena was already in place and has the ability to easily store inputs from multiple users, we were able to solve non-financial problems thrown at us by the COVID crisis.  In less than a day, we created a new data cube and templates to track PPE inventory (masks, gloves, gowns, etc.)  at all locations throughout the state.  Users enter their daily inventory allowing purchasing and operations to quickly see the status and move supplies where they are most needed.  Additionally, we are able to capture and compile COVID related costs for required reporting on government stimulus funds.

Choosing Vena as a partner is a decision you'll be grateful for at the end of your next budget cycle.  Take the time to think through the things you want to achieve and design your data cube(s) with future flexibility in mind.  Find the right person in your organization to champion the product and give them time to focus on implementing it well.

name: Frank U.
title: Worth the investment for intuitive financial planning
answers:
Vena is Excel-based, which is helpful for just about anyone in FP&A. The level of complexity  in the instance really depends on the goals & skill set of the FP&A team in question, and the investment in time a group is willing to train on the software.  The complexity can come from writing calc scripts in Vena, creating links to external data sources, or just utilizing Excel formulas.  

It's also very flexible; one can write static reports that can be manually changed as needed if standard formats are required, or more dynamic reports that can automatically detect changes in account mapping, which is a big time saver for a businesses that needs to add revenue or expense accounts.

Vena has obviously been working on automating connections with external data sources like Salesforce, which expands its usefulness.  After the initial setup, this can be a big time saver, but the setup can take considerable time.

The sense of community has been good for us, as we joined a local area meetup to get ideas on what other FP&A teams were using the software for and found we could be using it better on our own team.  We also attended the annual user conference which was fun and very educational.

The support staff is always helpful & responsive, and the account manager & coach we've worked with have been helpful.

There are few downsides, but here are a couple:

- for me, the "year: attribute" function can be tricky - when straddling fiscal years in terms of loading data (say you're closing FY20 but have FY21 open at the same time), I've been burned loading data to the incorrect fiscal year, and have had to go back and zero out an entire period's worth of data, re-load, change the year attribute to be correct, and then load the data correctly.  This is user error, of course, but I wish Vena had a way to grab the date of transaction and automatically flag the load or provide some type of warning, or at least provide an "undo" feature to go back to the prior dataset. 

- there are several different ways to do things, which is actually a huge positive, but it also can cause some issues when researching in the knowledge base.  Some of the solutions seem like they could be handled in a simpler fashion but require the use of calc scripts, etc.

Our business is highly transactional, which means we have lots of data and need to look at it in various ways from an operational standpoint.  We are just now getting to a point of using statistical accounts to load prior year data and current data so we can start to trend operational metrics.  We are also loading bookings data from salesforce using a data connector which will be very useful.  Beyond that, the use of multi-dynamic mapping should simplify our tying-out process after loading final values each month/quarter/year between Vena and our in-house accounting system.

All of this has and will continue to save time for our small FP&A team.  Eventually, we'd like to get to a place where our business partners/VPs can use Vena as well to further streamline our budgeting process.

name: Radu C.
title: Great tool for forecasts and budget
answers:
Vena is a powerful tool for developing and sharing forecasts and budgets. This application has allowed me to create powerful agile input templates for the end users to enter their forecast or budget projections. Vena makes the consolidation of this data easy: the consolidated data is displayed in reports and is easily refreshed with the push of a button.

The fact that Vena relies on Excel makes the learning curve less steep for some users. The entire setup process can be done internally as opposed to relying on second party consultants. Reports and input forms are built in Excel and while there is some learning required to master the mapping and data querying processes, it is fairly easy to comprehend.

Setting up and maintaining data cubes is intuitive and quick. Data hierarchies and dimensions can be either set up through the web interface (drag and drop type), mass upload via CSV file, or a combination of both techniques.

Vena relies heavily on Excel and therefore a robust knowledge of this tool is required to fully leverage the application's capabilities. Mistakes can easily be made if some users are unclear as to how the mapping process works. I wish there would be more control features in place to limit the type of input that some group of users can make.

The permissions setup process is a little too complex, with different overlapping layers of permissions. Setting up users can be challenging at first.

The mapping process in Excel can be time consuming for large report files. Each intersection cell needs to be mapped and although several cells can be mapped simultaneously, the process is still slower than querying data via Excel formula (as some applications allow). Mapping cells is done solely through a pop-up window in Excel and mapping cannot be copied through the standard Excel copy-paste feature. Also, mapping can become extremely slow on larger files (40+ sheets), with the Vena pop-up window taking as long as one minute to appear in these cases.

Vena helps us tackle the challenge of consolidating data from different user groups. We no longer have to maintain different copies on local computers or shared drives. Instead, we can all work on the same files simultaneously and the data entered is automatically consolidated in the Vena cloud database. Consolidation of user input was a challenge across an organization of our size. With Vena, we can simply hit the refresh button, and all data populates the fields which are mapped.
Be clear on your goals from the start then evaluate Vena on each of those points.
